{{Infobox company | name = Acne Studios | logo = Acne-Studios-logo.png | logo_size = 220 | type = Private | foundation = 1997 | founder = [[Jonny Johansson]] | location_city = [[Stockholm]] | location_country = [[Sweden]] | location = | origins = | key_people = [[Jonny Johansson]], creative director
[[Mikael Schiller]], executive chairman
Mattias Magnusson, CEO | area_served = | industry = [[Fashion]] | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | owner = | company_slogan = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.acnestudios.com}} }} '''Acne Studios''' is a multidisciplinary [[luxury goods|luxury]] [[fashion]] house based in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. Founded in 1996 as part of the creative collective ACNE, an acronym for Associated Computer Nerd Enterprises{{Cite web |url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/2015/03/25/jonny-johansson-tomas-skoging-acne-interview/ |title="If We Love It, Then People Will Love It." – A Discussion with ACNE Sweden |first=Chris |last=Danforth |date=25 March 2015 |website=[[Highsnobiety]] |access-date=11 October 2017 |language=en-US}} that was later changed to Ambition to Create Novel Expressions,{{cite magazine |url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/fashion/jonny-johansson/ |title=Jonny Johansson |date=21 November 2008 |magazine=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] |accessdate=9 April 2018}} the fashion house specializes in men's and women's [[ready-to-wear]] fashion, footwear, accessories and [[denim]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.acnestudios.com/us/en/about/about.html |title=About |website=AcneStudios.com |language=en |access-date=12 July 2017}} Founder and Creative Director Jonny Johannson's interest in photography, art, architecture and contemporary culture has helped Acne Studios to become a respected creator of clothing, publications, furniture, exhibitions and special collaborations.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/15/fashion/15ACNE.html |title=Stockholm Label Acne Wants to Be Known for More Than Jeans |first=Eric |last=Wilson |date=14 October 2009 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126713970005151659 |title=Sweden's Conceptual Fashion |first=J. S. |last=Marcus |date=26 February 2010 |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/acne-a-clear-winner-783462.html |title=Acne: A clear winner |first=Kay |last=Barron |date=18 February 2008 |newspaper=[[The Independent]] }} ==Background== Acne Studios was founded in 1996 in Stockholm, Sweden as part of the creative collective ACNE that focused on [[graphic design]], film, production and [[advertising]]. In 1997, cofounder [[Jonny Johansson]] created 100 pairs of raw [[denim]] jeans with red stitching and gave them away to friends and family. ''[[Wallpaper (magazine)|Wallpaper*]]'' and ''[[Vogue Paris]]'' quickly picked up on the popularity of the jeans and Acne Studios rapidly expanded their fashion offering outside of denim.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2013/jun/25/acne-10-things-fashion-brand |title=Acne: 10 things you should know about the hot fashion brand |first=Lauren |last=Cochrane |date=25 June 2013 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=9 April 2018}} In 2006, Acne Studios became a standalone company and separated from other entities within the collective ACNE such as Acne Film, Acne Advertising and Acne Digital, at the same time launching their [[e-commerce]]. Since launching, Acne Studios has grown into a global fashion house with retail stores around the world including [[Paris]], [[London]], [[New York City|New York]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Antwerp]] and [[Tokyo]], offering women's and men's ready-to-wear collections, showing at [[Paris Fashion Week]] twice a year and turning over $215 million annually in 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/fashion/alltherage/la-ar-acne-studios-opens-5000-square-foot-store-in-downtown-la-20131218-story.html |title=Acne Studios opens 5,000-square-foot store in downtown L.A. |first=Booth |last=Moore |date=18 December 2013 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] }} == Products == Acne Studios design men's and women's [[ready-to-wear]] fashion, footwear, denim, and accessories including handbags, small leather goods, and eyewear. Acne Studios stages [[Runway (fashion)|runway]] fashion shows for its women's Fall/Winter and Spring/Summer collections twice a year == Acne Studios Blå Konst == On April 6, 2017, Acne Studios relaunched its denim collection under the name Acne Studios Blå Konst (meaning "Blue Art" in Swedish) at all of their retail locations and on Acnestudios.com. This launch consists of men's and women's ready-to-wear, jeans, and accessories. In addition, an Acne Studios Blå Konst pop-up shop located in Tokyo's Shibuya district was opened to showcase the launch, which it houses exclusively. Six new denim styles including the North, River, and Land for men and the Climb, South, and Log for women have replaced the range of existing denim products. While these jean styles are permanent, the Blå Konst ready-to-wear collection will be updated seasonally.{{cite web |url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/bof-exclusive/acne-reboots-denim-strategy |title=Acne Reboots Denim Strategy |first=Daniel |last=Björk |date=20 March 2017 |website=[[The Business of Fashion]] |accessdate=9 April 2018}} == Acne Studios face motif collection == On August 17, 2017, Acne Studios launched its face motif collection{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.esquire.com/style/mens-fashion/news/a57081/acne-face-motif-collection-campaign/ |title=Acne Studios Just Launched One of the Coolest Campaigns We've Seen in a While |first=Jonathan |last=Evans |date=17 August 2017 |magazine=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |access-date=27 September 2017 |language=en}}, featuring patches of an emoticon face with two small circles and a long rectangle. Having first been introduced in their Autumn/Winter 2013 collection as a clutch{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.vogue.it/en/trends/the-trend-blog/2013/10/clutch-acne-studios |title=The clutch bags by Acne Studios |first=Selene |last=Oliva |date=31 October 2013 |magazine=[[Vogue Italia]] |access-date=27 September 2017}}, the face motif was featured in a unisex collection of ready-to-wear and accessories. ==''Acne Paper''== Acne Studios avoids traditional forms of [[marketing]] and advertising, choosing instead to publish a biannual magazine called ''[[Acne Paper]]''.{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/82754772-fbe0-11de-9c29-00144feab49a.html#axzz1VHadqqf0 |title=The boom in branded magazines |first=Lucie |last=Greene |date=8 January 2010 |newspaper=[[Financial Times]] |subscription=yes}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/paper-dreams-the-latest-issue-of-acnes-magazine-2329538.html |title=Paper dreams: The latest issue of Acne's magazine |first=Susannah |last=Frankel |date=31 July 2011 |newspaper=The Independent}} ''Acne Paper'' covers the disciplines of art, fashion, photography, design, architecture, academia, and culture. Each issue is based around a theme that is interpreted by selected contributors from their field of expertise. Contributors to ''Acne Paper'' have included [[Carine Roitfeld]], [[Noam Chomsky]], [[David Lynch]], [[Lord Snowdon]], [[Azzedine Alaïa]], [[Mario Testino]], [[Sarah Moon]], [[Tilda Swinton]] and [[Paolo Roversi]]. The fifteenth and final issue was published in 2014; Acne Paper has since been discontinued. ==Stores== Acne Studios has retail locations around the world including [[Stockholm]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Berlin]], [[New York City|New York]], [[San Francisco]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Milan]], [[Melbourne]], [[Sydney]], [[Antwerp]], [[London]], [[Paris]], [[Oslo]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Tokyo]], [[Seoul]], [[Beijing]], and [[Shanghai]].{{cite web |url=http://www.acnestudios.com/stores/ |title=Find a store |website=AcneStudios.com }} Acne Studios' Stockholm flagship store on [[Norrmalmstorg]] was the location of the 1973 bank robbery and subsequent hostage situation that gave rise to the term [[Stockholm Syndrome]] for the psychological phenomenon in which hostages express empathy and sympathy toward their captors. Acne Studios' first location in Italy, Piazza del Carmine, opened in June 2017. Acne Studios San Francisco opened in July, marking its second location in California. == Campaigns == In September 2016, Acne Studios announced its Fall/Winter 2016 campaign, shot by British photographer [[David Sims (photographer)|David Sims]]. The series was photographed in three parts, and each was presented globally- from posters plastered on the walls during [[Paris Fashion Week]] and Hong Kong's [[Golden Week (China)|Golden week]], on streetcars in Milan, and to digital images at London's Harrods. {{Cite magazine |url=http://wwd.com/business-news/media/acne-studios-david-sims-fall-ad-campaign-jonny-johansson-10519987/ |title=Acne Studios Taps David Sims for Fall Campaign |last=Socha |first=Miles |date=2 September 2016 |magazine=[[Women's Wear Daily|WWD]] |access-date=11 July 2017 |language=en-US}} For the Spring/Summer 2017 campaign, [[Paolo Roversi]] shot a portrait series featuring creatives around the world, such as [[Golshifteh Farahani]], [[Fatima Al Qadiri]], and [[Hayv Kahraman]]. The photography series was exhibited outdoors in New York, Paris, Milan, and Hong Kong. {{Cite magazine |url=http://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/acne-studios-spring-campaign-10775768/ |title=Acne Studios Unveils Spring Campaign |last=Garced |first=Kristi |date=2 February 2017 |magazine=WWD |access-date=11 July 2017 |language=en-US}} For the introduction of Acne Studios Blå Konst, [[Collier Schorr]] shot the campaign featured on the homepage of AcneStudios.com. These photographs launched online along with the new products on April 6, 2017. ==Collaborations== Acne Studios has collaborated widely with representatives from the creative industries to produce limited edition collections.{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324678604578340402927911328 |title=How to Succeed in Fashion Without Trying Too Hard |first=Lynn |last=Yaeger |date=15 March 2013 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal}} Some examples include a range of bikes with the world’s oldest bike manufacturer [[Bianchi Bicycles]],{{cite magazine |url=http://www.wallpaper.com/fashion/acnebianchi-bicycle/2997 |title=Acne/Bianchi bicycle |magazine=Wallpaper* |date=15 January 2009}} a furniture line of sofas based on Swedish designer [[Carl Malmsten]]’s sofa Nya Berlin,{{cite web |url=http://www.londondesignfestival.com/events/acne |title=Events |website=The London Design Festival}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/house-and-home/acne-launches-furniture-range-1879588.html |title=Acne launches furniture range |date=26 January 2010 |newspaper=The Independent}} a capsule collection with couture house [[Lanvin (clothing)|Lanvin]],{{cite magazine |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2008/12/23/acnelanvin-blue-collection-launches |title=An Outbreak Of Acne |first=Leisa |last=Barnett |magazine=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]] |date=23 December 2008}} an art installation and a collection with artist [[Katerina Jebb]],{{cite web |url=http://modeconnect.com/video-acne-13-objects-documented-katerina-jebb-untitled-no-1 |title=ACNE 13: Objects documented by Katerina Jebb |first=Pierre |last=Delarue |website=Modeconnect |date=15 April 2013}} a cross-gender blouse collection with transsexual magazine ''Candy'', an art book and blue shirt line with [[Lord Snowdon]],{{cite web |url=http://www.itsnicethat.com/articles/acne-snowdon-blue |title=An oldie but a goodie. Acne studios' magnificent Snowdon Blue |first=James |last=Cartwright |date=7 January 2013 |website=It's Nice That.com}} limited edition prints with [[William Wegman (photographer)|William Wegman]],{{cite web |url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2013/03/13/william-wegman-shoots-amazing-acne-studios-springsummer-2013-dog-campaign/ |title=William Wegman Shoots Amazing Acne Studios Spring/Summer 2013 Dog Campaign |date=13 March 2013 |website=Highsnobiety}} a rodeo-themed book and capsule collection inspired by Bruce of Los Angeles,{{cite magazine |url=http://www.elle.com/news/fashion-style/acne-studios-bruce-of-los-angeles-rodeo |title=Acne Studios Celebrates the Rodeo in a Second Photography Book |first=Kelsey |last=Garcia |date=17 May 2013 |magazine=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]}} a collection based around artworks by abstract Swedish pioneer [[Hilma af Klint]],{{cite magazine |url=http://en.vogue.fr/fashion/fashion-news/diaporama/acne-studios-celebrates-hilma-af-klint-jonny-johansson-accessories-t-shirts-sweatshirts/17952 |title=Acne Studios celebrates Hilma af Klint |first=Margaux |last=Krehl |date=13 March 2014 |magazine=[[Vogue Paris]]}} and a capsule collection with Liberty London.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.elleuk.com/star-style/news/acne-studios-x-liberty-london-capsule-collection-jonny-johansson-london-fashion-week |title=Acne Studios x Liberty London |first=Maybelle |last=Morgan |date=14 February 2014 |magazine=Elle UK |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515184611/http://www.elleuk.com/star-style/news/acne-studios-x-liberty-london-capsule-collection-jonny-johansson-london-fashion-week |archive-date=15 May 2014}} More recent collaborations include a limited-edition monograph and unisex silk pajama collection with American sculptor Peter Schlesinger{{Cite web |url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2015/04/28/acne-studios-peter-schlesinger/ |title=Acne Studios Peter Schlesinger Capsule Collection |date=11 July 2017 |website=Highsnobiety |access-date=11 July 2017}}, small leather goods monogrammed with Jack Pierson's custom lettering,{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.vogue.com/article/acne-studios-jack-pierson-collaboration |title=Acne Studios Unveils an Arty Collab With Jack Pierson |magazine=Vogue |access-date=11 July 2017 |language=en}} and a custom rug collection for Acne Studios' Madison Ave. location designed by British designer [[Max Lamb]] and Swedish rug company Kasthall.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/acne-studios-debuts-rugs-with-max-lamb-and-kasthall |title=Acne Studios Debuts Rugs with Max Lamb and Kasthall |magazine=[[Architectural Digest]] |accessdate=9 April 2018}} == Publications == In 2012, Acne Studios and photographer Lord Snowdon collaborated to launch Acne Studios' first published book: ''Snowdon Blue''. The publication included Snowdon's portraits of [[David Bowie]], [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Manolo Blahnik|Monolo Blahnik]] and more, all dressed in blue shirts. A limited-edition collection of 8 styles of blue button-ups alluding to the book's visuals were also created and sold both in-store and online.{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.wallpaper.com/fashion/acne-launches-the-snowdon-blue-project#56775 |title=Acne launches the Snowdon Blue project |date=8 May 2012 |magazine=Wallpaper* |access-date=11 July 2017}} Acne Studios' second photography book, ''Bruce of Los Angeles: Rodeo,'' presents photographer [[Bruce Bellas]]' shots of American cowboys. In addition, [[Jonny Johansson|Jonny Johannson]] designed a collection of western-themed tops, jeans, and boots to embody the classic American theme.{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.elle.com/fashion/news/a23133/acne-studios-bruce-of-los-angeles-rodeo/ |title=Acne Studios Celebrates the Rodeo in a Second Photography Book |date=17 May 2013 |magazine=Elle |access-date=11 July 2017 |language=en}} ''Peter Schlesinger Sculpture'' was released by Acne Studios in conjunction with a capsule collection of silk loungewear on April 29, 2015. The book features photos of over 150 of American sculptor Peter Schlesinger's works since the 1980s, and was shot by Eric Boman. The monograph's photos were accompanied by Swedish text and printed on Japanese paper. The recent Spring/Summer 2017 campaign, shot by Paolo Roversi, was also released as a limited-edition publication and featured interviews of those photographed.{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/fashion/article/34589/1/acne-studios-trades-models-for-artists-and-writers |title=Acne Studios trades models for artists and writers |date=3 February 2017 |first=Vanessa |last=Hsieh |magazine=[[Dazed]] |access-date=11 July 2017 |language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.acnestudios.com}} * [http://www.acne.se/ Acne Group official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304054721/http://pressfiles.acnestudios.com/Acne-Studios-Environmental-Strategy.pdf Acne Studios Environmental Strategy] [[Category:Companies based in Stockholm County]] [[Category:Clothing brands of Stockholm]] [[Category:Clothing companies of Sweden]] [[Category:High fashion brands]] [[Category:Luxury brands]] [[Category:Swedish brands]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Sweden]]

{{redirect|Antiphonarium Codex Montpellier|information on the codex of polyphonic motets|Montpellier Codex}}
The '''Antiphonary tonary missal of St. Benigne''' (also called '''Antiphonarium Codex Montpellier''' or '''Tonary of Saint-Bénigne of Dijon''') was supposed to be written in the last years of the 10th century, when the Abbot [[William of Volpiano]] at St. [[Benignus of Dijon]] reformed the liturgy of several monasteries in Burgundy. The chant manuscript records mainly Western plainchant of the Roman-Frankish [[proper (liturgy)|proper mass]] and part of the chant sung during the [[matins]] ("[[Gregorian chant]]"), but unlike the common form of the [[Roman Gradual|Gradual]] and of the [[Antiphonary]], William organized his manuscript according to the chant genre ([[antiphon]]s with psalmody, [[alleluia]] verses, [[gradual]]s, [[offertory|offertories]], and [[trope (music)|proses]] for the missal part), and these sections were subdivided into eight parts according to the [[Hagiopolitan Octoechos#Tonary|octoechos]]. This disposition followed the order of a [[tonary]], but William of Volpiano wrote not only the incipits of the classified chant, he wrote the complete chant text with the music in central French [[neume]]s which were still written in ''campo aperto'', and added a second alphabetic notation of his own invention for the melodic structure of the codified chant.
== Historical background ==
This particular type of a fully notated [[tonary]] only appeared in Burgundy and Normandy. It can be regarded as a characteristic document of a certain school founded by [[William of Volpiano]], who was reforming abbot at St. [[Benignus of Dijon]] since 989. In 1001 he followed a request by [[Richard II, Duke of Normandy|Duke Richard II]] and became first abbot at the [[Abbey of Fécamp]] which was a reforming centre of monasticism in Normandy.
Only this manuscript was written during the time of William by the same hand as several other manuscripts of the Library of the Medical Faculty of Montpellier (today "Bibliothèque interuniversitaire de Médecin") which all belong to St. Bénigne. It is not known, whether it was really written by William of Volpiano in person. The few things known about him can be read in a hagiographic source, the ''Vita domni Willelmi'' in fourteen chapters written by his disciple, the Burgundian monk Raoul Glaber in 1031, and revised probably by demand of the later Abbot John of Fécamp during the late 11th century.<ref>See the edition of Véronique Gazeau and Monique Goullet ([[#Gaz08|2008]]).</ref> William was born as son of the Alemannic Duke Robert of Volpiano at the citadel of his family on the island S. Giulio of the Lake Orta in Piedmont. The legend said that [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Otto]] had conquered this island, while William was born, so the Emperor became his patron and he was educated as a monk and made his clerical career at [[Cluny Abbey]] during the reform of [[Majolus of Cluny|Abbot Majolus]] who continued the [[Cluniac reforms|reform]] of his predecessor [[Odo of Cluny|Odo]] and supported reforms connected with papal politics under influence of the Ottonic Emperors. Concerning liturgical reforms, Emperor [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto I]] already emphasized the need for a reform of monasticism in Southern Italy and to abandon local liturgies in favour of the Roman rite, a kind of second Carolingian reform, and he already wished to "liberate" Arab Sicily and to organize church provinces of the island which was mainly populated by Muslims and by a Greek Christians. His plan failed after the catastrophic defeat of his son [[Otto II, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto II]] near [[Reggio Calabria|Reggio]], but the role of [[Cluny Abbey|Cluny]] as a centre for liturgical reforms had increased in Ottonic times.
William's reforms were not only concerned with liturgy and the new design of local chant books, but also with the construction of new churches and buildings for abandoned abbeys, with canon law, with the organization of grammar schools and even rural communities of Normandy. It was typical for a career at [[Cluny Abbey]] to get one of the most prestigious positions as a cantor and to continue as a reforming abbot in another Abbey, which was subjected to this powerful and ambitious Abbey. As Abbot of St. Benignus William reformed several monasteries of Burgundy, Lorraine and the [[Île-de-France]]. There are some testimonies like the ''Libellus de revelatione, edificatione et auctoritate Fiscannensis monasterii'', a chronicle of Fécamp, which reports certain ressentments against Norman culture and its local liturgical customs.<ref>Gazeau ([[#Gaz02|2002, 44]]).</ref> William appeared as a [[Cluniac reform]]er, but studies of his liturgical reform especially of the Office chant for Fécamp did not confirm, that he just removed local in favour of Cluniac customs.<ref>See the dissertation of Olivier Diard ([[#Dia00|2000]]) which proves that he "corrected" chants as Raoul Glaber called it, and he also added own compositions which can only found in the two manuscripts, and he respected certain customs of the local school.</ref> Within the reform and the history of Norman monasticism, the reform of William of Volpiano was neither the beginning nor its climax, as a reformer he had to find a balance between local needs and problems and certain interests of the Cluniac Abbot, of the Pope, and of the Norman patrons, whose founding activities cultivated a new form of policy. William contributed to this history with the foundation of an own school.
According to Véronique Gazeau he did not spend too much time in Normandy during the period about 30 years of his Norman activities, but nevertheless his school could be established, because he ordained his students as abbots.<ref>Gazeau ([[#Gaz02|2002, 39f]]).</ref> He was not only Abbot at Fécamp, but also at Jumièges between 1015 and 1017. He became first Abbot of Bernay, a foundation of [[Judith of Brittany|Countess Judith]], [[Richard II, Duke of Normandy|Richard II]]'s wife, in 1025. By order of Duke Robert he left Fécamp for John of Ravenna in 1028, before 1027 he was assisted at the Abbey at Bernay by a ''custos'' Thierry, an elder and experienced monk and prior from Saint-Bénigne of Dijon. Before he followed Suppo as prior at Mont-Saint-Michel in 1023. These administrative changes were caused by the establishment of monastic centres during certain periods, in which some Abbeys were no longer guided by an abbot, but by a prior of the community who was often called "custos", and several new foundations did not always start as an Abbey, they were subordinated to older abbeys. These monastic centres which had the control over various monasteries including former abbeys, were used to control new foundations as well as to obey liturgical and administrative reforms. This practice was continued after William's death, [[Abbey of Fécamp|Fécamp]] and [[Benignus of Dijon|Saint-Bénigne]] were controlled by one abbot between 1052 and 1054: Abbot John of Ravenna. When the new founded monasteries became abbeys, the abbots were usually chosen among the monks of Fécamp.
Only few writings by William have survived in the Abbey of Fécamp, but it is not always easy to decide, if the collection of Montpellier which belonged obviously to the library of the Abbey St. Benignus of Dijon, had this Abbey as destination. Michel Huglo remarked that the last part of the manuscript H.159, the real Antiphonary with antiphons and responsories for the [[Matins]], was continued by the 13th-century copy of the Antiphonary of the Abbey of Fécamp (Rouen, Bibliothèque municipale, Ms. 254, olim A.190).<ref>{{cite web |last=Huglo |first=Michel |title=Tonary |url=http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/28104 |work=[[New Grove]] Music Online. Oxford Music Online |accessdate=30 December 2011 }}</ref> So the destination of the Tonary of Saint-Bénigne is still a matter of discussion. On the other hand, customs of St. Bénigne like the liturgy for the patron can also be found in other Abbeys as Fécamp and Bernay, and the tonaries of Dijon (Montpellier, Ms. H159), of Fécamp (Rouen, Ms. 244, olim A.261), and of Jumièges (Rouen, Ms. 248, olim A.339) are so consistent that they can be regarded as documents of one school which can be ascribed to William of Volpiano.
== The alphabetic notation invented by William of Volpiano ==
One of William's innovations as a cantor and notator was an alphabetic pitch notation. Its point of reference was the Boethian diagramm, which displayed the double octave of the ''[[Tone system#Syst.C3.AAma Ametabolon.2C an overview of the tone system|systema teleion]]'' in the [[Diatonic genus|diatonic]] (semitonium-tonus-tonus), the [[Chromatic genus|chromatic]] (semitonium-semitonium-trihemitonium), and the [[Enharmonic genus|enharmonic]] [[tetrachord]] (diesis-diesis-ditonus). The different positions were represented by alphabetical letters, except the dieses which had special signs not unlike the tyronic letters used by [[Boethius]]:
[[File:William of Volpiano's alphabetic notation.jpg|center|650px|thumb|alt=Introduction into William of Volpiano's aplphabetic notation|Alphabetic notation invented by [[William of Volpiano]]: the letters referred to the Boethian diagramme]]
This alphabetic pitch notation does not only offer insights into microtonal shifts used by the cantors of this local school, it also proves that the common projection of the piano keyboard on the medieval tone system is inadequate. Like many other letter systems used since the 8th century, also the system of William of Volpiano represented the positions of the Boethian diagramm, and the enharmonic signs used for the dieses represented not a change into another genus, but microtonal attractions within the diatonic melos of a certain mode.<ref>Nancy Phillips ([[#Phi00|2000]]) offers an overview.</ref>
Concerning the diesis [[Guido of Arezzo]] wrote about 1026 in his treatise ''[[Micrologus]]'' that the diesis sharpens the usual tonus between re-mi (a-b; d-e; g-h or h-i) with the proportion 9:8 by a proportion of 7:6 (a-˫; d-˧; g-Γ or h-˥).<ref>See: {{Citation | edition = Hildesheim 1963 reprint | publisher = Typis San-Blasianis | last = Guido D'Arezzo | author-link = Guido of Arezzo | editor-last = Gerbert | editor-first = Martin | contribution = Micrologus | title = Scriptores ecclesiastici de musica sacra potissimum | volume = 2 | pages = 11 | place = St Blaise | year = 1784 | url = http://www.chmtl.indiana.edu/tml/9th-11th/GUIMIC_TEXT.html }}.</ref> Guido's explanation, how to find this intervall at the monochord, made it already evident that the diesis, taken from the "enharmonic" division of the tetrachord, was used here as a microtonal shift in different melodic modes of the diatonic genus.
== Composition of the manuscript ==
The Tonary of Saint-Bénigne of Dijon is organized in a very rare form of a fully notated [[tonary]], which serves like a fully notated music manuscript for mass ([[gradual]]) and office chant ([[antiphonary]]).<ref>It has been preserved in the Bibliothèque Inter-Universitaire, Section Médecine, at the [[University of Montpellier]] (Ms. H.159), and it was issued as a facsimile in the series illustrating the relics of ancient musical notation, ''Paléographie Musicale'' (first series, Solesmes, [[#PM05|1896]]; reprinted twice: Bern, 1972; Solesmes, 1995).</ref>
The first division of the chant book is between the book's gradual (ff. 13r-155v) and an antiphonary fragment (ff. 156r-162v) which has the [[Matins]] for Palm Sunday, St. Blasius and St. Hylarius in the conventional liturgical order, but with tonal rubrics.<ref>This form was also used in a contemporary Aquitanian abridged [[antiphonary]] or [[breviary]] (Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale, fonds lat., Ms. 1085), the only difference is that every chant is just represented by an incipit and that the tonal classification is a Latin ordinal according to the system of Hucbald (tonus I-VIII). William of Volpiano followed also here the shape of another [[tonary]] type and used classifications like [https://archive.org/stream/palographiemus0105gaja#page/308/mode/2up "P TE"] for "Plagi tetrardi" as they were already used in the 9th-century Gradual-Sacramentary of Saint-Denis (Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale, fonds lat., Ms. 118).</ref> The last leaf was added from another book to use the blank versoside for additions on the last pages written by other hands, chant notated in adiastematic neumes but without alphabetic notation and even diastematic neumes with alphabetic notation (ff. 160r-163r).<ref>See [http://manuscrits.biu-montpellier.fr/images/159161rZ.jpg folio 161 recto].</ref>
The gradual itself with proper mass chant is divided into six parts: The first are antiphons ([[introit]]s and [[Communion (chant)|communions]]) (ff. 13r-53r). The next three parts are chant genres which precedes lessons: [[Alleluia (chant)|alleluia]] verses for [[Gospel Book|gospel]] readings (ff. 53v-69r), the benedictiones (hymnus trium puerorum) for [[Lectionary|prophetic]] readings (ff. 75r-76v), and the [[Responsory|graduels]] for [[epistle]] readings (ff. 77r-98v). The last two parts are an ''offertorial'' (ff. 99r-151r) and a [[Tract (liturgy)|tractus]] collection (ff. 69r-74v; 151v-155v), dedicated to the genre which replace the alleluia verses during fasten time for all kinds of scriptural readings.<ref>An exact description of its content can be found in the analytic table of the facsimile edition in the serial of [[#PM05|Paléographie musicale]] ([https://archive.org/stream/palographiemus0105gaja#page/n13/mode/2up VIII, 9-18]).</ref>
The third level of division are the eight parts according to the oktoechos in the order of autentus protus, plagi proti, autentus deuterus etc. In the first part, every tonal section has all introits according to the liturgical year cycle and then all communions according to the liturgical order. The whole disposition is not new, but it is identical with tonaries from different regions of the [[Cluniac Reforms|Cluniac Monastic Association]]. The only difference is, that every chant is not represented by an incipit, it is fully notated in neumes and in alphabetic notation as well. Thanks to this manuscript, even cantors who do not know the chant, can memorize the melody together with its tonus.
As an example might serve the Introitus "Repleatur os meum" used as a refrain for psalm 70 during the procession into the church, at the beginning of the morning mass on Saturday before Pentecost. The introit was written in the first part of the antiphons and is quite at the beginning of the deuterus section (written as heading on each page), hence an introit in the 3rd tone or "autentus deuterus": [[File:Tonary of Saint-Bénigne de Dijon.jpg|thumb|900px|center|alt=Montpellier, Bibliothèque Inter-Universitaire, Section Médecine, Ms. H159, f. 25v|The introit "Repleatur os meum" of the authentic deuterus mode with the psalm 70 "In te domine speravi" and its ''differentia'' "ii" notated with "amen" ([[Montpellier]], Bibliothèque interuniversitaire de Médecine, Ms. [[#MOfH159|H159]], f. 25v)]] The beginning with the psalm incipit and the ending of the psalmody, here called ''differentia'' no. "ii", follows the antiphon. The antiphons of the entrance (introits) have the gradual order of the mass as a rubric at the margin (on a verso page as here: left), i.e. the serial for the day with ''gradual'' ('''R'''), ''alleluia'' ('''All''') or ''tractus'' ('''TR'''), ''offertorium'' ('''OF'''), and ''communio'' ('''CO'''). A conventional [[tonary]] with the list of ''differentiae'' was also attached to the beginning of the manuscript.<ref>See the coloured reproductions of the folios [http://manuscrits.biu-montpellier.fr/images/159011rZ.jpg 11 recto] and [http://manuscrits.biu-montpellier.fr/images/159011vZ.jpg 11 verso] and the transcription in the analytic table of the PM edition ([https://archive.org/stream/palographiemus0105gaja#page/n15/mode/2up 1901, VIII, 10]).</ref> It was used as an index to find the ''differentia'' no. ii or melodic ending used during the recitation of the [[psalm]] - here the incipit refers to psalm 70 of the [[Vulgata]]. This tonary is preceded by an alleluia collection written in central French neumes in campo aperto.
The style of William of Volpiano's tonary which follows, is unique, and Michel Huglo called it one of the finest tonaries which survived in the manuscript collections today. The scribe used red ink for the chant text and different colours to decorate its initials, while the neume and the alphabetic notation was written in black ink.<ref>See folio [http://manuscrits.biu-montpellier.fr/images/159014rZ.jpg 14 recto].</ref>
== William of Volpiano's contribution to the evolution of musical notation ==
William of Volpiano's innovation of the notation system did not change the habits of central French neume notation, it just added an own alphabetic pitch notation. Often it was not clear how the letters refer to the neumes. Letter groups usually refer to the group of a ligature, but sometimes neumes were added as well to the letters to help the reading cantor for the coordination.
Among the monastic reforms of [[Normandy]] [[William of Volpiano]] was an important protagonist among the local abbots, but his alphabetic notation was only used over the following centuries in the Norman monasteries of his school, but never in the later Italo-Norman manuscripts which were rather influenced by the [[Saint Martial school|Aquitanian school]] (a few manuscripts used central French neumes, but without alphabetic notation). Within the Cluniac Monastic Association, the cantors of the following generation like [[Adémar de Chabannes]] who was taught by his uncle Roger at [[Abbey of Saint Martial, Limoges|Saint-Martial Abbey of Limoges]] ([[Aquitaine]]), developed a new diastematic neume notation which allowed to indicate the ligatures, even if they were separated by the vertical disposition according to their pitch class. His innovation was imitated by Italian cantors, first in Northern Italy than in other reform centres of the 11th century like [[Benevento]] and [[Monte Cassino]]. During the 12th century one are two lines were added to help the scribe and the reader for a constant vertical orientation.
After the first generation of fully notated neume manuscripts written since the early 10th century,<ref>One of the earliest Southern French testimonies of local melodic neume notation («notation protoaquitaine») can be found in a gradual written about 890 (Albi, Bibliothèque municipale Rochegude, Ms. 44), where only 27 pieces have musical notation and usually only in some parts. Nevertheless, the scriptor left space for the notator (see the Christmas masses on [http://archivesnumeriques.mediatheques.grand-albigeois.fr/_images/OEB/RES_MS044/index.htm folio 5r–5v] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319062306/http://archivesnumeriques.mediatheques.grand-albigeois.fr/_images/OEB/RES_MS044/index.htm |date=March 19, 2014 }}), even if it had not always been used for later additions of neumes. </ref> the particular notation system represent a transition between the adiastematic and diastematic neumes. During the 11th century a lot of local traditions, different from the chant repertory of the Roman-Frankish reform, were codified the first time in diastematic neumes: [[Beneventan chant|Old Beneventan chant]] (Beneventan neumes without lines), [[Aquileian Rite|Ravenna chant]] (Beneventan neumes), [[Old Roman chant]] (Roman neumes without lines), [[Ambrosian chant|Ambrosian]] or Milanese chant (square neumes on a penta- or tetragramm).
== See also == * [[Adémar de Chabannes]] * [[Benignus of Dijon|St. Benignus of Dijon]] * [[Cluny Abbey]] * [[Cluniac Reforms]] * [[Fécamp Abbey]] * [[Guido of Arezzo]]'s [[Micrologus]] * [[Judith of Brittany]] * [[Pope Leo VIII]] * [[Majolus of Cluny]] * [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor]] * [[Richard II, Duke of Normandy]] * [[Tonary]] * [[William of Volpiano]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Boogiepop'' series}} [[File:Boogiepop logo.png|thumb|The logo used for the English releases of Boogiepop products]] The {{nihongo|'''''Boogiepop'' series'''|ブギーポップシリーズ|Bugīpoppu shirīzu}} of Japanese [[light novels]] is written by [[Kouhei Kadono]] and illustrated by [[Kouji Ogata]]. It includes titles from different media, each connected by repeating characters and related plots. Presented in [[Vignette (literature)|vignettes]], each chapter presents the reader with only snapshots of what is happening, leaving them to find clues to understand the greater plot.<ref name="ultimate1">{{cite web|url=http://www.gomanga.com/news/boogiepop_01.php|last=Smith|first=Lesley|title=Boogiepop: The Ultimate Guide (Part 1 of 4)|date=2006-01-30|accessdate=2006-06-20|publisher=[[Seven Seas Entertainment]]}}</ref>
''Boogiepop'' is best characterized as [[young adult literature|young adult]] [[fiction]] and is credited with starting the light novel trend in Japan.<ref name="sselicense">{{cite web|url=http://www.gomanga.com/news/press_015.php|title=Seven Seas Enters the World of Boogiepop|date=2005-10-31|accessdate=2006-06-20|publisher=[[Seven Seas Entertainment]]}}</ref> By March 2000, two million copies of Kadono's Boogiepop light novels works were in print.<ref name="bnlvol1">{{cite book|last=Kadono|first=Kouhei|authorlink=Kouhei Kadono|date=2006-04-24|title=Boogiepop Doesn't Laugh|publisher=[[Seven Seas Entertainment]]|isbn=978-1-933164-18-2|page=187}}</ref> The [[Boogiepop Phantom|anime]] and [[Boogiepop and Others#Film adaptation|live action film]] inspired by the original light novels have been released in English by [[The Right Stuf International]], while [[Seven Seas Entertainment]] released four of the light novels and the [[manga]].
== Overview == {{See also|List of Boogiepop media}}
To face the "enemies of the world", the ''[[shinigami]]'' Boogiepop automatically rises to the surface. In Boogiepop's world, the Towa Organization, a shadowy group seeking to control humanity, managed to capture an alien organism who had taken the form of a [[evolution|highly evolved]] human. By studying him, the Towa Organization was able to create synthetic humans, people who have been artificially enhanced with special abilities. The mission of the Towa Organization and its agents is to find and kill MPLS, people who are more evolved than others and possess special abilities. However, Boogiepop will not let the Towa Organization get its way and he is not alone in his efforts.
The Boogiepop series is very much about the characters: their relationships, their pasts, their memories. This is especially true for how their pasts molded them into the people they are today. It can also be seen through scenes being presented from the perspective of different characters, and how the individual casts a different "feel" by how they relate to events.<ref name="bpdvd1com">DVD commentary featuring Jeff Thompson and Joe DiGiorgi (August 2001) ''Boogiepop Phantom Evolution 1''</ref> Another important theme is change. How the world changes and our different perceptions of this change, especially how one's perception of things changes as they grow up.<ref name="bpdvd2com">DVD commentary featuring Jeff Thompson, [[Crispin Freeman]], and Rachel Lillie (2001) ''Boogiepop Phantom Evolution 2''</ref> ''[[Boogiepop Phantom]]'' is also highly [[metaphorical]], with a character or an image representing much more than face value.<ref name="bpdvd4com">DVD commentary featuring Jeff Thompson and Angora Deb (2002) ''Boogiepop Phantom Evolution 4''</ref> It is also "a show about the inter-related nature of people's lives and the concept that they know of as time."<ref name=afbp>{{cite web|url=http://www.animefringe.com/magazine/02.01/feature/1/|title=Boogiepop Phantom - A Myriad of Moments Past and Present|last=Arnold|first=Adam|accessdate=2006-08-07|date=January 2002|publisher=Animefringe}}</ref>
Kadono has published fourteen light novels and has serialized [[short stories]] in ''Dengegi HP'',<ref name="mcshorts">{{cite web|url=http://mostlycloudy.net/~ballzapalooza/boogiepop/ss.htm.ja.euc |last=Collette |first=Chris |title=Boogiepop Short Stories |accessdate=2006-06-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060504013426/http://mostlycloudy.net/~ballzapalooza/boogiepop/ss.htm.ja.euc |archivedate=2006-05-04 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> many of which have been published as a four-volume series about Pete Beat, a member of the Towa Organization. Two manga serials have been drawn for this series, which were serialized in ''[[Dengeki Daioh]]''<ref name="ultimate3">{{cite web|url=http://www.gomanga.com/news/boogiepop_03.php|last=Smith|first=Lesley|title=Boogiepop: The Ultimate Guide (Part 3 of 4)|date=2006-01-30|accessdate=2006-06-20|publisher=[[Seven Seas Entertainment]]}}</ref> and ''Dengeki Animation''.<ref name="ultimate1" /> In 2000, the [[anime]] series ''Boogiepop Phantom'' aired on Japanese television; a drama CD, featuring [[Kaori Shimizu (voice actress)|Kaori Shimizu]], was released to promote this series.<ref name="ultimate3" /> Later that year, the movie ''[[Boogiepop and Others]]'' was released.<ref name="ultimate1" />
== Characters == {{Main|List of Boogiepop characters}} Each Boogiepop title has its own cast of characters, and many of these characters will make appearances in more than one title, but there are only four central characters that are consistently at the center of the plot.
; {{nihongo|[[Boogiepop (character)|Boogiepop]]|ブギーポップ|Bugīpoppu}}
The [[shinigami]] whispered of among the female students of Shinyo Academy, few people know that Boogiepop actually exists. Normally dormant, Boogiepop rises to the surface when enemies of the world appear. Boogiepop's appearance and voice are ambiguous: they seem both masculine and feminine at the same time. However, hidden beneath his signature black cloak and black, pipe-shaped hat, little is ever seen of him. Straight-faced and to the point, Boogiepop acts as mechanical as he claims to be. Boogiepop speaks in an archaic manner, and seems fond of whistling the overture to [[Wagner|Wagner's]] ''[[Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg]]''.
; {{nihongo|[[Miyashita Touka|Touka Miyashita]]|宮下藤花|Miyashita Tōka}}
An ordinary, happy school girl at Shinyo Academy, Miyashita is in love with her boyfriend, Keiji Takeda, and close friends with Suema. Not particularly good at school, she does not stand out in any way. Unknown to most, she was hospitalized as a child, and this saw her life change, though even Miyashita herself does not seem to know the truth of what happened, and was simply told that she had been possessed by a [[kitsune]]. Unknowingly, when the world is in trouble, she carries a Spalding sports bag containing the effects of Boogiepop, her [[dissociative identity disorder|alternate personality]]. She has no recollection of her time as Boogiepop, and alters her memories to explain the blanks.
; {{nihongo|[[Kirima Nagi|Nagi Kirima]]|霧間凪|Kirima Nagi}}
Known as the Fire Witch to many, Kirima has made few friends due the way she distances herself from others: she knows that she is too dangerous for 'normal' people to associate with. She has a [[messianic complex]], and seeks to save the world from whatever may threaten it. As such, whenever there are unusual happenings within the city, Kirima can be found investigating what has happened. In the past, she had spent a period of time in hospital. A combination of the events from that period of her life, as well as the death of her father, the famous writer Kirima Seiichi, brought her to follow this path in life. Extremely gifted both physically and intellectually, she has the basic tools she needs to carry out her self-appointed mission.
; {{nihongo|[[Suema Kazuko|Kazuko Suema]]|末間和子|Suema Kazuko}}
As a result of a childhood trauma, Suema has developed an unusual fascination with [[criminal psychology|criminal]] and [[abnormal psychology]], as well as the desire to not let anything occur around her without her knowing. As a result of this, she desperately seeks the truth about the unexplained events happening in her city, and meddles with forces best left untouched. Good friends with Miyashita Touka, Suema appreciates how she so open and unconditionally accepting of her, and looks out for her friend. She seeks to be closer with Kirima Nagi, who seems to know the answers to the questions that have haunted her all these years. Despite her involvement in several incidents, she has yet to see Boogiepop in action.
== Internationalisation == The Right Stuf International licensed ''Boogiepop Phantom'' for English release in 2001.<ref name="annbplicence">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/article.php?id=19|title=Anime Dates and Delays|date=2001-01-06|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> They [[dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbed]] the series and have distributed it in the US in both [[VHS]] and [[DVD]] formats. The series is distributed in the UK by [[ADV Films]] and across Australia and New Zealand by [[Madman Entertainment]]. ''Boogiepop Phantom'' has also been localised and released in [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], France, Italy, Spain and the [[Netherlands]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2015}}
In 2004, The Right Stuf International acquired the film ''Boogiepop and Others''.<ref name="annbolicense">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/article.php?id=5278|title=New Right Stuf Acquisitions|date=2004-07-31|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> It has been released on DVD in Japanese with English [[subtitles]], and is distributed in both the US and Europe, along with a director's [[Audio commentary (DVD)|commentary]] and behind the scenes interviews with the cast.
In 2005, Seven Seas Entertainment announced they had acquired the rights to publish the Boogiepop novels and manga in English.<ref name="sselicense" /> Before 2018, they released the first three novels and the sixth, as well as the ''Boogiepop Doesn't Laugh'' and "Boogiepop Dual" manga. Seven Seas Entertainment has announced that they will re-release the novels in an omnibus format.
== Reception ==
=== Impact and influence ===
''Boogiepop and Others'' won the Fourth [[Dengeki Novel Prize]] in 1997 and was released in the Dengeki Book Collection in 1998 where it gained popularity.<ref name="baohob">History of Boogiepop (1 March 2005) ''Boogiepop and Others''</ref> It is credited with popularizing light novels,<ref name="sselicense" /> as well as redefining young adult fiction in Japan.<ref name="annbr1rev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/reviews/display.php?id=1017|last=Martin|first=Theron|title=Boogiepop Returns: VS Imaginator, Part 1|date=2006-07-27|accessdate=2006-07-28|publisher=Anime News Network}}</ref> It was later adapted into a live action film by Ryu Kaneda, a two-volume manga by Kouji Ogata and served as the inspiration for a [[soundtrack]] composed by [[Yuki Kajiura]].<ref name="ultimate1" /> ''Boogiepop and Others'' also sets the scene for the anime, ''Boogiepop Phantom'', which has its backstory loosely based on the climax of the light novel. Having already gained a strong readership among High School and University age men, the release of ''[[Boogiepop Returns: VS Imaginator Part 1]]'' was met with overwhelming support. By the time the ''Boogiepop and Others'' film was released, the Boogiepop series was a bestseller, with over two million copies in print.<ref name="baohob" />
=== Reviews === The Boogiepop series has received high praise from critics. ''Boogiepop Phantom'' has received the most exposure, where it is often compared to ''[[Serial Experiments Lain]]'' and ''[[Paranoia Agent]]''.<ref name="ultimate2">{{cite web|url=http://www.gomanga.com/news/boogiepop_02.php|last=Smith|first=Lesley|title=Boogiepop: The Ultimate Guide (Part 2 of 4)|date=2006-01-30|accessdate=2006-06-20|publisher=[[Seven Seas Entertainment]]}}</ref> It has been noted that the series is "not your average anime", and one that "demands your attention".<ref name="ntusabprev">{{cite book|last=Lopez|first=Javier|date=January 2003|title=[[Newtype USA]]|publisher=[[A.D. Vision]]|pages=??}}</ref> While the fine detail the animators went into with the visuals has received much praise, bland character designs have been noted as one of the series' flaws, though "astute viewers may notice some rather interesting [...] differences between the various characters."<ref name="annev1rev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/reviews/display.php?id=170|last=Macdonald|first=Christopher|title=Boogiepop Phantom Evolution 1 DVD|date=2001-11-15|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> The soundtrack has received much acclaim, not only for the [[background music]] and [[voice actor]] performances, but also the detail that went into the [[sound effects]].<ref name="aodvdbprev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animeondvd.com/reviews2/disc_reviews/123.php|last=Beveridge|first=Chris|title=Boogiepop Phantom|date=2001-10-30|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=Anime on DVD|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050411155900/http://www.animeondvd.com/reviews2/disc_reviews/123.php|archivedate=2005-04-11|df=}}</ref> The presentation of the storyline was well received, but it was acknowledged that not everyone would be interested in following the subtle clues in each episode<ref name="thembprev">{{cite web|url=http://themanime.org/viewreview.php?id=68|last=Cynova|first=Isaac|title=Boogiepop Phantom|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=T.H.E.M. Anime Reviews}}</ref> and the "artistically deliberate sense of confusion".<ref name="sfbprev">{{cite web|url=http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue253/anime.html |last=Robinson |first=Tasha |title=Boogiepop Phantom |accessdate=2006-06-23 |publisher=SciFi.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509093331/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue253/anime.html |archivedate=2006-05-09 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A common complaint, however, is that there are many loose ends, mainly relating to the backstory,<ref name="sfbprev"/> leaving the series "with more questions than answers".<ref name="ntusabprev" />
Far less critiqued, the ''Boogiepop and Others'' film fares less well than its sequel. Whilst the characters and plot were well received, the [[special effects]] and costumes have been described as "campy", but "par for the course of something of this level and budget".<ref name="aodvdborev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animeondvd.com/reviews2/disc_reviews/3885.php |last=Beveridge |first=Chris |title=Boogiepop and Others |date=2 July 2005 |accessdate=2006-06-23 |publisher=Anime on DVD |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061101173507/http://www.animeondvd.com/reviews2/disc_reviews/3885.php |archivedate=2006-11-01 |df= }}</ref> The movie is, however, cited as being easier to watch, and is recommended to fans of the anime, so as to gain "a complete understanding of the Boogiepop events".<ref name="mementoborev">{{cite web|url=http://www.designchronicle.com/memento/archives/boogiepop_and_others.html|title=Boogiepop and Others|date=11 February 2004|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=Memento}}</ref>
The ''Boogiepop and Others'' novel has received more favorable reviews, though these have mostly focused on the translation, which has been cited as "a standard against which future Japanese novel translations are judged".<ref name="annbonrev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/reviews/display.php?id=959|last=Martin|first=Theron|title=Boogiepop and Others|date=13 March 2006|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> It has also received praise for ripping "the rules of narrative wide open",<ref name="rtobonrev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/columns/rightturnonly.php?id=25|last=Santos|first=Carlo|title=RIGHT TURN ONLY!!|date=21 March 2006|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> especially for how it allows the characters to grow on the reader.<ref name="aodvdbonrev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animeondvd.com/reviews2/manga/manga.php?manga_view=2051|last=Pine|first=Jarred|title=Boogiepop|date=17 March 2006|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=Anime on DVD|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060325061759/http://www.animeondvd.com/reviews2/manga/manga.php?manga_view=2051|archivedate=25 March 2006|df=}}</ref> ''Boogiepop Returns: VS Imaginator Part 1'' continues receiving positive feedback for its easy-to-read style and excellent translation, as well as its use of atmosphere and characters. The main flaw, however, is the briefness of the title, which has clearly been used to set up the sequel.<ref name="annbr1rev" />
''Boogiepop Doesn't Laugh'' has received generally favorable reviews, particularly for capturing some of the more complicated scenes better than the original light novel. This makes the plot easier to follow, and captures the urgency of the climactic battle.<ref name="rtobdl2rev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/columns/rightturnonly.php?id=34|last=Santos|first=Carlo|title=RIGHT TURN ONLY!!|date=25 July 2006|accessdate=2006-07-26|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> However, it has been noted that breaking the complicated plot of ''Boogiepop and Others'' into a multi-volume manga results in individually weak volumes.<ref name="rtobdl1rev">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/columns/rightturnonly.php?id=28|last=Santos|first=Carlo|title=RIGHT TURN ONLY!!|date=2 May 2006|accessdate=2006-06-23|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> As with ''Boogiepop Phantom'', the character designs have been noted as "lookalike and nondescript", which can make some of the events difficult to follow. The art has also been described as "washed out and dull".<ref name="rtobdl2rev" />

[[File:Brown paper bag texture.jpg|thumb|An individual darker than a brown paper bag was denied privileges]] The '''Brown Paper Bag Test''' in African-American [[oral history]] was a form of racial discrimination practiced within the [[African Americans|African-American]] community by comparing an individual's skin tone to the color of a [[Paper bag|brown paper bag]]. The test was allegedly used as a way to determine whether or not an individual could have certain privileges; only those with a skin color that matched or was lighter than a brown paper bag were allowed admission or membership privileges. The test was believed by many to be used in the 20th century by many African-American social institutions such as sororities, fraternities, and churches.{{cite web|last1=Pilgram|first1=David|title=Brown Paper Bag Test|url=http://www.ferris.edu/news/JimCrow/question/feb14/index.htm|website=Ferris State University|publisher=Ferris State University|accessdate=16 October 2015}} The term is also used in reference to larger issues of class and social stratification within the African American population. [[Audrey Elisa Kerr]] has researched and documented the practice.[http://www.southernct.edu/academics/schools/arts/departments/english/fullandparttimefaculty/kerr.html Dr. Kerr] is a professor at Southern Connecticut State University. ==Color discrimination== [[File:2012 IAAF World Indoor by Mardetanha3245 (cropped).JPG|thumb|Athletes with various skin tones]] [[Privilege (social inequality)|Privilege]] has long been associated with [[skin tone]] in the [[African-American]] [[community]]. This is related to the [[enslavement]] of individuals based on [[race (human categorization)|race]]. Mixed-race children of white fathers were sometimes given [[wikt:privilege|privilege]]s ranging from more desirable work, apprenticeships or formal [[education]], allocation of property, or even freedom from enslavement. African Americans "contributed to colorism because they have benefited from the privilege of having a skin color closer to that of Whites and have embraced the notion that privilege comes with having light skin in America".{{cite web|title=African Americans Still Victims of Colorism|url=http://www.racismreview.com/blog/2011/03/26/african-americans-still-victims-of-colorism/|website=Racism Review|publisher=Wordpress|accessdate=20 November 2015}} Lighter-skinned people of color were accorded certain social and economic advantages over darker-skinned people of color, even while suffering [[discrimination]]. According to Gordon, "light-skinned blacks formed exclusive clubs" after slavery was abolished in the United States.{{cite web|title=Skin-Deep Discrimination|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/GiveMeABreak/story?id=548303&page=1|website=ABC News|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=23 October 2015}} Some clubs were called "Blue Vein Societies", suggesting that if an individual's skin was light enough to show the blue cast of veins, they had more European ancestry (and, therefore, higher social standing.) Such discrimination was resented by African Americans with darker complexions. According to [[Henry Louis Gates Jr.]], in his book ''The Future of the Race'' (1996), the practice of the brown paper bag test may have originated in [[New Orleans, LA]], where there was a substantial third class of free people of color dating from the French colonial era.{{cite web|last1=Maxwell|first1=Bill|title=The paper bag test|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/08/31/Columns/The_paper_bag_test.shtml|website=St. Petersburg Times|publisher=Tampa Bay Times|accessdate=23 October 2015}} The test was related to ideas of [[beauty]], in which some people believed that lighter skin and more European features, in general, were more attractive. From 1900 until about 1950, "paper bag parties" are said to have taken place in neighborhoods of major [[United States|American]] cities with a high concentration of African Americans. Many churches, fraternities, and nightclubs used the "brown paper bag" principle as a test for entrance. People at these organizations would take a brown paper bag and hold it against a person's skin. If a person was lighter than the bag, he or she was admitted. People whose skin was not lighter than a brown paper bag were denied entry.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/10995079/page/4/ "Did Hurricane Katrina reveal a historic reality?" Excerpt from [[Michael Eric Dyson]]'s (2006) ''Come Hell or High Water'']
There is, too, a curious color dynamic that persists in our culture. In fact, New Orleans invented the brown paper bag party — usually at a gathering in a home — where anyone darker than the bag attached to the door was denied entrance. The brown bag criterion survives as a metaphor for how the black cultural elite quite literally establishes caste along color lines within black life. On my many trips to New Orleans, whether to lecture at one of its universities or colleges, to preach from one of its pulpits, or to speak at an empowerment seminar during the annual Essence Music Festival, I have observed color politics at work among black folk. The cruel color code has to be defeated by our love for one another. —[[Michael Eric Dyson]], excerpt from ''Come Hell or High Water''.{{cite book|last=Dyson|first=Michael Eric|title=Come hell or high water : Hurricane Katrina and the color of disaster|year=2007|publisher=Basic Civitas|location=New York|isbn=978-0465017720|edition=Pbk.}}
[[Historically black colleges and universities]] used the brown paper bag test as a way to critique candidates for admission.{{cite web|last1=Carter|first1=Jarrett|title=Bringing Back the Brown Paper Bag Test to HBCUs|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jarrett-l-carter/bringing-back-the-brown-p_b_3059700.html|website=Hoff Post Black Voices|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=29 October 2015}} A person's skin tone could affect whether they were admitted to a top school. For instance, Audrey Elisa Kerr refers to colleges requiring applicants to send personal photos.{{cite book|last1=Kerri|first1=Audrey Elisa|title=The Paper Bag Principle: Class, Colorism, and Rumor and the Case of Black Washington, Part 3|date=2006|publisher=University of Tennessee Press|page=93|accessdate=31 October 2015}} Kerr mentioned how this practice took place at a popular [[Historically black colleges and universities|HBCU]], Howard University. Dr. Arnold relayed to Kerr a story concerning young women at Howard. Dr. Arnold had heard colorism was a factor when it came to admission to Howard. Discrimination was also practiced by fraternities and sororities, whose members self-selected others like themselves, generally those reflecting partial European ancestry.{{cite web|title=Paper Bag Test: Letter From 1928 Addresses Black Fraternity And Sorority Colorism At Howard University|url=http://www.watchtheyard.com/history/brown-paper-bag/|website=watchtheyard|publisher=WatchTheYard.|accessdate=31 October 2015}} Multi-racial people who had been free before the American Civil War attempted to distinguish themselves from the mass of freedmen after the war, who appeared to be mostly of African descent and had been confined to slavery. ==Colorism through the centuries== [[File:Herriman 1902.png|thumb|Creole person in 1902]] The offspring of African men and white women were often born into freedom, because of their mothers' legal status of slave vs. free, regardless of color.{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Heather|title=How Slavery Affected African American Families|url=http://nationalhumanitiescenter.org/tserve/freedom/1609-1865/essays/aafamilies.htm|website=National Humanities Center|publisher=National Humanities Center|accessdate=21 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Slavery and Indentured Servants|url=https://memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/awlaw3/slavery.html|website=Law Library of Congress|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=17 February 2016}} A law, established in Virginia and other colonies in the 17th century, dictated that the legal status of these children would be determined by that of their mothers, rather than by their father's, in opposition to the tradition of English common law. These free descendants became well-established, with descendants moving to frontier regions of [[Virginia]], [[North Carolina]] and west as areas opened up. Some prominent Americans were descendants of these early free families, for instance, [[Ralph Bunche]], who served as ambassador to the United Nations.{{cite web|last1=Heinegg|first1=Paul|title=Free African Americans of Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Maryland and Delaware|url=http://www.freeafricanamericans.com/|accessdate=15 Feb 2008}} As early as the 18th century, travelers remarked on the variety of color and features seen in slaves in Virginia, as European ancestry was obvious. Light-skinned slaves, some of whom were descendants of masters and their sons, were sometimes given better treatment on plantations, with domestic jobs inside the master's house, including as companions or maids to his legal children.{{cite web|title=Household Slavery|url=https://www.boundless.com/u-s-history/textbooks/boundless-u-s-history-textbook/slavery-and-reform-1820-1840-16/slavery-in-the-u-s-122/household-slavery-656-1313/|publisher=boundless|accessdate=21 November 2015}} Some of them were educated, or at least allowed to learn to read. Occasionally the master may have arranged for an apprenticeship for a mixed-race son and freed him upon its completion, especially in the first two decades after the American Revolution, when numerous slaves were freed in the Upper South. In this region, from the Revolution to 1810, the percentage of people of color who were free increased from 1 to more than 10 percent. By 1810, 75% of blacks in Delaware were free.Peter Kolchin, ''American Slavery: 1619-1877'', New York: Hill and Wang, 1994 Pbk, pp.78 and 81 Newly imported Africans and African Americans with less visible European ancestry were used in hard field labor, and abuse was more frequent in the fields. As tensions concerning slave uprisings rose in the 19th century, slave states imposed more restrictions, including prohibitions on educating slaves and on slaves' movements. These slaves could be punished for trying to learn to read and write. In Louisiana especially, [[Creoles of color]] had long comprised a third class during the years of slavery. They had achieved a high level of literacy and sophistication under the French and Spanish rule, becoming educated, taking the names of white fathers or lovers, and often receiving property from the white men involved with their families. Many became artisans, property owners, and sometimes slaveholders themselves. Unlike in the Upper South, where free African Americans varied widely in appearance, free people of color in New Orleans and the Deep South tended to be light-skinned due to generations of intermarriage with people of European ancestry. After the United States negotiated the Louisiana Purchase, more Americans settled in New Orleans, bringing with them their binary approach to society, in which each person was classified only as black or white. They began to curtail the privileges of Creoles of color.Peter Kolchin, ''American Slavery: 1619-1877'', New York: Hill and Wang, 1994 Pbk, p. 83 ==See also== * [[Black is Beautiful]] * [[Colorism]] * [[Good hair (phrase)]] * [[High yellow]] * [[Louisiana Creole people]] * [[Mulatto]] * [[Octoroon]] * [[One-Drop Rule]] * [[Passing (racial identity)]] * [[Pencil test (South Africa)]] * [[Quadroon]] * [[School Daze]] ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |title=The Color Complex |last=Russell |first=Kathy |first2=Midge |last2=Wilson |first3=Ronald |last3=Hall |date=1993-10-01 |publisher=Anchor |location=New York |isbn=978-0-385-47161-9 |page=208 }} * {{Cite web |last=Williams |first=Lena |title=The Many Shades of Bigotry |date=1992-11-22 |publisher=New York Times |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE6DA133DF931A15752C1A964958260 }} ==External links== * [http://www.sptimes.com/2003/08/31/Columns/The_paper_bag_test.shtml THE PAPER BAG TEST], an editorial by Bill Maxwell about blacks discriminating against blacks, ''St. Petersburg Times'', August 31, 2003, discusses the history of the test. * [http://abcnews.go.com/2020/GiveMeABreak/Story?id=548303&page=1 Skin-Deep Discrimination, ABC News, March 4, 2005] * [http://www.classypac.fr/ Classypac] [[Category:African-American cultural history]] [[Category:Colorism]] [[Category:History of racism in the United States]]

{{Infobox Historic building |image= Charlottenborg København.jpg |caption= Charlottenborg |name= Charlottenborg Palace |location_town= [[Copenhagen]] |location_country=[[Denmark]] |architect= [[Ewert Janssen]] |client= [[Ulrik Frederik Gyldenløve]] |engineer= |construction_start_date= 3 April 1673 |completion_date= 1677
1683 (fourth wing) |date_demolished= |cost= |structural_system= |style= [[Baroque architecture|Baroque]] }} {{confuse|Charlottenburg Palace}} '''Charlottenborg Palace''' ({{lang-da|Charlottenborg Slot}}) is a large town mansion located on the corner of [[Kongens Nytorv]] and [[Nyhavn]] in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Originally built as a residence for [[Ulrik Frederik Gyldenløve, Count of Laurvig|Ulrik Frederik Gyldenløve]], it has served as the base of the [[Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts]] since its foundation in 1754. Today it also houses [[Kunsthal Charlottenborg]], an institution for contemporary art, and Danmarks Kunstbibliotek, the Royal Art Library. ==History== ===Gyldenløve's mansion=== [[Image:Charlottenborg (Jacob Coning).jpg|thumb|left||Charlottenborg painted by [[Jacob Coning]] in 1694 as seen from the garden.]] The site was donated by King [[Christian V of Denmark|Christian V]] to his half brother [[Ulrik Frederik Gyldenløve]] on 22 March 1669 in connection with the establishment of [[Kongens Nytorv]]. Gyldenløve built his new mansion from 1672 to 1683 as the first building on the new square.{{cite web|url=http://www.kobenhavnshistorie.dk/bog/kko/c/kko_c-10.html|title=Charlottenborg, Kongens Nytorv 1|publisher=Selskabet for Københavns Historie|language=Danish|accessdate=2011-10-15}} The main wing and two lateral wings were built from 1672 to 1677, probably under the architect [[Ewert Janssen]]. In 1783 mansion was extended with a rear, fourth wing was designed by [[Lambert van Haven]] . The bricks used were brought from [[Kalø Castle]] in [[Jutland]] which Gyldenløve owned and had pulled down. In his old age, the large mansion became too big for Gyldenløve who sold it to the dowager queen Charlotte Amalie in 1700, hence the name. Gyldenløve built a new, smaller mansion on the corner of [[Bredgade]] and [[Dronningens Tværgade]] which became known as "Gyldenløve's little mansion", now [[Moltke's Mansion]], after a later owner, where he lived until his death in 1705. After King [[Christian V]]´s death in 1699 the [[Queen Mother]], [[Charlotte Amalie of Hesse-Cassel|Charlotte Amalie]], purchased the Palace for 50,000 Danish crowns and it was renamed Charlottenborg Palace. In 1714, when the Queen Downer died, the place was passed to King [[Christian VI of Denmark|Christian VI]]. Renovations began in 1736-1737, and its use and users shifted for a period of time. A small theater was constructed and used for various concerts, operas and theatrical performances. The Palace Garden contained the [[University of Copenhagen Botanical Garden|Botanical Garden]] between 1778 - 1872. ===The Royal Danish Academy of Arts=== [[File:Charlottenborg 1742.jpg|thumb|200px|Charlottenborg in 1742]] In 1701, the old Academy of Arts began its activities in the Palace. The small school slowly grew and was finally formally inaugurated in the Charlottenborg Palace on March 31, 1754. In 1787, the ownership of the Palace was transferred to [[The Royal Danish Academy of Art]]. The Academy still occupies the Palace. ==Architecture== Charlottenborg is a four-winged, three-storey building designed in the [[Baroque architecture|Dutch Baroque]] style but also with some Italian influence.{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_historie/Danmark_efter_1945/Charlottenborg|title=Charlottenborg|language=Danish|publisher=Gyldendal|accessdate=2011-10-16}} The main wing towards the square has a central risalit flanked by two more pronounced, two-bay corner risalit. All three are topped by balustrades. The central risalit is decorated with Corinthian pilasters and a Tuscan/Doric portal with balcony The facade has sandstone decorations and window pediments. The lower rear wing consists of three pavilions. The central pavilion has a Tuscan arcade below, niches with busts above, and a lantern on the copper-covered roof. ===Interior=== The floor plan is remniscient of French castles. It has a [[piano nobile]] with a banguet hall above the main entrance, with access to the balcony, a ground floor with lower ceilings, and a second floors for servants with even lower ones. Ths arrangement became characteristic of mansions and upper-class town houses in the entire 18th century. In the rear wing, above the arcade, there is a well-preserved domed Baroque room with a splendid stucco ceiling. ==Contemporary activities== * [[Royal Danish Academy of Art]] * [[Kunsthal Charlottenborg]], Exhibition Hall * [[Danish National Art Library ]] ==Cultural references== * In the 2015 drama film ''[[The Danish Girl (film)|The Danish Girl]]'', Charlottenborg is the location where [[Lili Elbe|Einar]] ([[Eddie Redmayne]]) and [[Gerda Wegener|Gerda]] ([[Alicia Vikander]]) meet as students at the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts.{{cite web|url=http://www.visitdenmark.com/denmark/tour-danish-girl-locations|title=Tour The Danish Girl locations|website=visitdenmark.dk|accessdate=9 October 2017}} ==See also== * [[Architecture of Denmark]] * [[Art of Denmark]] * [[Charlottenborg (disambiguation)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons|Charlottenborg Slot}} * [http://www.kunstakademiet.dk Det Kongelige Danske Kunstakademi] * [http://www.kunsthalcharlottenborg.dk Kunsthal Charlottenborg] * [http://www.kunstbib.dk Danmarks Kunstbibliotek] {{Copenhagen historic houses}} {{Copenhagen}} {{Coord|55.680|N|12.587|E|display=title|source:dewiki}} [[Category:Palaces in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Culture in Copenhagen]] [[Category:History of Copenhagen]] [[Category:Houses completed in 1677]] [[Category:Baroque architecture in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts]] [[Category:Houses in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Gammelholm]] [[Category:1677 establishments in Denmark]]
